Photograph album
The Lowell Thomas Institute of Communicating Arts at Human Resources Center, A Presentation to Lowell Thomas
[Album cover]

Page 1: The Students of Human Resources School Respectfully Present this Album to Lowell Thomas. Author, Explorer, Historian, Journalist. Whose Leadership in the Communicating Arts Has Brought The Affairs of Man To Generations Yet Unborn. On the occasion of the establishment of the Lowell Thomas Institute of Communicating Arts at Human Resources School. October 23, 1968.
Page 2: The Children of Human Resources School accepted as class projects the development of a symbol which would embrace the essence of the Lowell Thomas Institute of Communication Arts[continued]
Page 3: Ours is a world of movement and change. A single day may see the creation of one government and the toppling of another[continued]

Page 4: The students themselves will be in charge of the entire process of developing a house organ which will be mailed each year to persons interested in the latest occurrence in Human Resources Center[continued]
Page 5: Visual
Page 6: Photo of child with mechanical hands. Even the most disabled child can learn to use the hand tools of communication in the proposed Creative Writing Laboratory
Page 7: Disabled child finger painting with woman beside him. The use of finger paints allows for self-expression and the development of creativity.
Page 8: Boy in wheelchair reading a newspaper. The daily newspaper is an important part of the educational process at Human Resources School.
Page 9: Disabled child. The photo laboratory enables the disabled child to achieve permanent visual records.
Page 10: Children in wheelchairs. A microviewer with an accompanying microfilm strip replaces burdensome textbooks for the disabled child.
Page 11: Student in wheelchair. A class newspaper is the student's first experience in the dissemination fact and opinion
Page 12: Man pointing at computer and a disabled student in wheelchair. Data storage and the functioning of the IBM 360/30 computer will be part of the course in orientation to communications
Page 13: Student in wheelchair. A microfilm reader brings the world of yesterday to the disabled pupil of today.
Page 14: Man pointing to printer and student in wheelchair. A computer printer delivers numbers which must be interpreted as messages.
Page 15: Disabled children. The science of keypunch operation is explained to disabled students in high school.
Page 16: Man standing and student in wheel chair. An electric punch card sorter allows information to be coded, classified and catalogued.
Page 17: Three disabled children watching a man standing and pointing to a globe. It is a challenge of teaching to bring to students the cultures of nations far removed.
Page 18: Black and white photo - Lowell Thomas standing with another man looking at an item, two women seated at table.
Page 19: Disabled children in a classroom setting. A film strip correlates words and pictures for the developing young mind.
Page 20: Children sitting in wheelchairs in a classroom; man with a projector. Even a complex scientific concept can be simplified through the use of appropriate communication devices.
Page 21: Girl sitting in a wheelchair. A visual can be enjoyed by a single student through an apparatus which coordinates sight and sound.
Page 22: Disabled child with an electric typewriter. A severely disabled child often can only effectively communicate through mechanical means.
Page 23: Auditory
Page 24: Children in wheelchairs sitting around a woman holding a story book. Even the youngest children in the elementary school learn the value of communication in their story telling hour.
Page 25: Some children in wheelchairs to the left and other disabled children sitting to the right, man playing a piano. The sound of music is also the sound of expression.
Page 26: Two disabled children by a record player. Learning to listen is involved in appreciating music forms and rhythm patterns.
Page 27: Man in wheelchair with headphones. The linguistic console enables a student to learn the languages of man.
Page 28: Man standing and holding an opened book. Through the use of an executone a student confined to his home can actively participate in classroom discussions.
Page 29: Girl in wheelchair with headphones. Alone in a busy library through the use of a self-contained record player.
Page 30: Man in wheelchair and a boy in a wheelchair with headphones. Radio International, Human Resources School's shortwave radio station, brings the entire world to disabled students.

Page 31: A quadriplegic woman in a wheelchair by a phone. The school's guidance counsellor, a quadriplegic, has had to develop special techniques to use standard communication instruments such as the telephone.
Page 32: Students in wheelchairs sitting around a table with a woman standing at the head of it. Oral communication, the art of dialogue, is heavily emphasized in the curriculum.
